step1.sentence: After three failed interviews in a row, he started to lose confidence in his abilities.

step2.story: The writer had published her first novel to warm reviews. The second had been received quietly. By the third manuscript, she had lost so much confidence in her instincts that she rewrote the opening chapter eleven times and could not tell anymore which version was best.

step3.story: The team had been performing well until a string of external setbacks — delayed supplies, a key client pulling back, a product recall that turned out to be a false alarm but consumed two months of focus. Morale had dropped, and with it individual confidence. The manager noticed the change not in output but in the conversations people were no longer having: no one was proposing new approaches, no one was pushing back in meetings. She organized a retrospective not to review the setbacks but to map what the team had handled well during them. It was the first time in months they had seen their own competence clearly. Confidence, once lost, sometimes just needed a mirror to return.
